title: Is anyone else scared of solipsism, that everyone and everything around you is just a figment of your imagination and you're actually all alone? - Quora

response.answer_text: Decades of work as a programmer has shaped my thinking about this sort of thing. You see, I’m used to seeing programs get moved from platform to platform. As you may know, it’s possible to still play computer games that were written in the 1980s*. I don’t mean remakes of the games; I mean the exact same games—the exact same code! These are programs that may have originally been stored on magnetic tapes. Over the years, they were copied from medium to medium. They may have once been played on RadioShack TRS-80 computers but now they’re running on cellphones. The same exact code. The lesson here is that the same program can be run on multiple platforms, and it’s the program that’s interesting, not the platform it runs on. Another analogy is books. Shakespeare wrote Hamlet on scraps of paper. It’s since been “run” in hardback books, paperback books, laptop screens, Kindles, and cellphones. (And, of course, on stage and screen.) The reading device changes. The text remains the same. The interesting scenes in Hamlet aren’t interesting because they’re printed on paper or on a screen. They’re interesting because of what’s happening with the plot and characters. Which reminds me of Ray Bradbury’s famous novel Fahrenheit 451. It’s set in a near-future dystopia, in which the government has ordered all books to be destroyed. So a resistance movement forms in which volunteers secretly memorize entire books. So, for a while, Don Quixote only “runs” inside some guy’s head. That’s the only copy of the book. It’s running on on a platform of neurons instead of paper and ink. Still, the story exists. Our Universe “runs” on something. The question of what it runs on is interesting, but it’s the same “game,” regardless of what it’s running on. It appears to run on a platform made out of atoms. But maybe that’s wrong. Maybe, as some folks have speculated, we’re living in a simulation. Okay, but the interesting stuff about my mom is interesting whether she’s made out of atoms or ones and zeros in some alien computer. The Laws of Physics may apply to matter, or maybe they’re the rules of a SimUniverse game. Either way, they affect me. As Shylock says, “If you prick me, do I not bleed?” Well, maybe I’m a sim, and I’m just sim-bleeding, but, either way, from my point-of-view, I’m bleeding. All of this is just as true if the entire Universe is “all in my head.” Maybe my head is the platform the Universe is running on. Still, it’s running. (If this is true. If my head is powerful enough to simulate an entire universe, that’s astounding! It’s astounding even if my brain cuts corners and only “renders” the bits I can see. I’m able to stand outside, look in one direction, then whip my head around and look in another. And my head is, apparently, able to keep up! It instantaneously renders all the stuff that was out of view a fraction of a second ago!) Even if it’s all in my head, the amazing thing is, I have no idea what my wife (or “wife” if she’s imaginary) is going to get me for my birthday. The Universe being in my head gives me no special advantages of foresight. Its as if the Universe is not in my head! It’s exactly like that from my point of view. If I just made up my wife and all of my friends—and all the the books I’ve ever read and all of the movies I’ve ever seen—then I’m creative genius! I invented giraffes and quasars and and the Grand Canyon and cayenne pepper! Or, if some aliens invented all of this, and I’m the only real person, trapped in their matrix, then they’re amazing programmers and I’m lucky to have the privilege of being able to live in their simulation! And I still don’t know what my wife (or “wife”) is getting me for my birthday!  * Colossal Cave Adventure

Basically, either the idea breaks you, or you just kinda accept it. My thoughts on it are: “what a fascinating idea, and yet so obvious that I should have thought of it myself. Sure, it’s depressing, but have the fundamentals of my life changed? Not really.” It’s essentially the same as questioning whether we live in a simulation. Is it a cool idea? Absolutely. Is it scary ? Like hell. Could it help you become more thoughtful and introspective? Possibly. Is free will a lie? Most likely. Is there a god? Is there a better end to all this? Very possibly not. But should that keep me from living life? And loving and caring for those around me? Does it change the fact that we are talking monkeys living on a pebble flying through space and time, who fuck around with literal fucking magic on a daily basis like it’s nothing spectacular, because we are the most intelligent species in our half of the universe, living in the best and most prosperous age ever experienced on earth? No. Not really. so keep your hands, arms and legs inside the cart at all times, and just have the time of your life! Seriously. You are so much more free than you realize! So what if solipsism is real or not? It just means that you have the opportunity to decide what makes Life worth living for YOU.
